lens.book_chapters: Part 1 (Chapters 1-4): Why Great Firms Fail — Ch 1: How Can Great Firms Fail?, Ch 2: Value Networks and the Impetus to Innovate, Ch 3: Disruptive Technological Change in Mechanical Excavators, Ch 4: What Goes Up, Can't Go Down
lens.lens_summary: Christensen's disruption framework reveals that Airbnb, once itself a disruptive entrant, has migrated upmarket into luxury experiences, professional hosting, and higher-fee tiers — following the exact 'northeast migration' pattern that leaves the low end of the market (affordable, mid-term, shared housing) exposed to a new disruptive entrant like Split Lease.

competitor_overview.primary_strength: Global brand recognition, massive network effects, and trust infrastructure (reviews, host guarantee, instant book) that make short-term vacation stays feel safe and frictionless — do NOT compete here.
competitor_overview.business_model: Two-sided marketplace charging guests a service fee (typically 14-16%) and hosts a 3% fee (or hosts-only pricing at 14-16%). Revenue scales with booking volume and average daily rate. This fee structure incentivizes Airbnb to push higher-priced listings and premium experiences, because a 14% fee on a $300/night luxury stay yields far more than on a $40/night shared room.
competitor_overview.user_base: Originally budget travelers and casual hosts renting spare rooms. Now increasingly affluent travelers seeking unique vacation experiences, plus professional hosts and property managers operating multiple listings as businesses. The original 'air mattress on someone's floor' user has been largely abandoned.
competitor_overview.brand_perception: Once seen as the scrappy, affordable alternative to hotels. Now perceived as expensive (often more than hotels after fees), corporate, and increasingly impersonal. Users feel nickel-and-dimed by cleaning fees and service charges. Trust in individual hosts has been partially replaced by trust in the Airbnb brand itself — a shift from peer-to-peer authenticity to platform-mediated commerce.

discovery.what_they_do: Airbnb invests heavily in aspirational marketing — 'Made possible by Hosts' campaigns, social media content showcasing unique properties (treehouses, castles, luxury villas), and Airbnb Categories (OMG!, Trending, Beachfront, etc.). Discovery is designed to inspire wanderlust and impulse browsing, not to solve a specific housing need. SEO and paid search capture intent-based traffic for vacation destinations.
discovery.framework_analysis: Christensen's value network concept (Ch 2) explains why Airbnb's discovery phase is tuned this way. Airbnb's value network is defined by metrics that matter to short-term vacation travelers: unique aesthetics, destination appeal, nightly rate flexibility, and aspirational experience quality. The 'rank-ordering of performance attributes' in Airbnb's current value network places visual appeal and location desirability above practical concerns like lease flexibility, roommate compatibility, or month-over-month cost stability. Discovery reflects the value network Airbnb has migrated into, not the one it started in.
discovery.what_nobody_in_category_does: Nobody in the shared housing category designs discovery around the specific life event that triggers a mid-term housing search — job relocation, semester abroad, medical travel, divorce transition, remote work trial. Discovery is always property-first, never situation-first. No platform asks 'What's happening in your life?' before showing listings. This means the entire category forces users into System 2 (deliberate, effortful) search mode when the emotional context of their situation could be used to guide them through a System 1 (intuitive, low-friction) path.

evidence.source: Ch 2: Value Networks and the Impetus to Innovate
evidence.observation: Christensen demonstrates that each value network has its own 'rank-ordering of the importance of various product performance attributes' and that these rankings 'differ markedly from that employed in other systems-of-use in a broadly defined industry.' Airbnb's discovery metrics (visual uniqueness, destination appeal, nightly rate) reflect a vacation value network, not a shared housing value network.
evidence.framework_interpretation: The attributes that matter for mid-term shared housing discovery — roommate compatibility signals, neighborhood livability for daily routines, commute proximity, total monthly cost transparency — are simply not in Airbnb's value network rank-ordering. They cannot optimize for these without de-optimizing for their core vacation market. This is structurally identical to how 14-inch drive makers could not optimize for the size and portability metrics that defined the 8-inch drive's value network.

evidence.source: Airbnb Categories launch and marketing strategy
evidence.observation: Airbnb Categories (OMG!, Mansions, Castles, etc.) organize discovery around aesthetic aspiration, not functional housing need. There is no category for 'affordable shared room near your new job' or 'quiet room for a traveling nurse's 13-week contract.'
evidence.framework_interpretation: This is the upmarket migration Christensen describes in Ch 4 — 'the focus of its energy had clearly shifted to the market for mid-range computers, such as file servers and engineering workstations.' Airbnb's discovery has shifted focus from practical housing to aspirational travel, just as Seagate shifted from desktop PCs to workstations.

search.what_they_do: Map-based search with robust filters: dates, guests, price range, property type, amenities, instant book, superhost. Search assumes you know your destination and dates. Monthly-stay filter exists but is clearly an afterthought — it was added years after launch and is poorly integrated. Filters are optimized for vacation parameters (pool, hot tub, waterfront) rather than livability parameters (quiet neighborhood, laundry, workspace, kitchen quality).
search.framework_analysis: Christensen's concept of 'overshooting' the market (Ch 1 Introduction, Principle #5) applies directly. Airbnb's search has overshot the needs of the mid-term housing seeker. The platform offers more features than this segment needs for vacation booking but misses what this segment actually requires: total cost calculators that include all fees over multi-week periods, roommate-fit indicators, neighborhood routine information (grocery, gym, transit commute times), and lease-style flexibility options. The technology has improved along a trajectory that the mid-term market doesn't value.
search.what_nobody_in_category_does: Nobody provides a search experience designed for stays longer than 2 weeks. Every platform in the category — Airbnb, Furnished Finder, even Craigslist — treats search as a point-in-time transaction: pick dates, see results. No platform helps you search iteratively over days or weeks, saving and comparing options as your plans solidify, sharing shortlists with a future roommate, or progressively narrowing based on how your needs evolve. The entire category assumes search is a single session, not a multi-day decision process.

evidence.source: Ch 1: How Can Great Firms Fail?
evidence.observation: Christensen demonstrates that disruptive technologies 'offered a different package of attributes valued only in emerging markets remote from, and unimportant to, the mainstream.' Airbnb's search filters offer the attribute package valued by vacation travelers (check-in flexibility, unique amenity filters) but not the package valued by mid-term housing seekers (total cost over lease, roommate compatibility, neighborhood daily-life quality).
evidence.framework_interpretation: Just as 5.25-inch drives offered 'a different package of attributes valued in desktop computing' that minicomputer makers couldn't see, a shared housing search optimized for lease-length cost, routine livability, and roommate fit offers a different attribute package that Airbnb's vacation-optimized search cannot serve without undermining its core UX.

evidence.source: Airbnb monthly stay search UX observation
evidence.observation: When searching for monthly stays, Airbnb still shows nightly rate prominently, with monthly discount as a secondary annotation. Cleaning fees and service fees are not shown until checkout. For a 3-month stay, the real cost can be 20-40% higher than the displayed nightly rate suggests. There is no 'total cost for your entire stay' shown on the search results page.
evidence.framework_interpretation: This is the classic value network mismatch Christensen describes. Airbnb's pricing display is optimized for the metric that matters in its vacation value network (nightly rate comparison) and fails to present the metric that matters in the mid-term housing value network (total monthly out-of-pocket).

listing_evaluation.what_they_do: Detailed listing pages with professional photography, descriptions, amenity lists, house rules, cancellation policy, location map, and — most importantly — a rich review system (star ratings per category + written reviews). Superhost badges provide trust signals. Photo quality has become a key differentiator, with Airbnb historically offering free professional photography to hosts.
listing_evaluation.framework_analysis: Christensen's analysis of how established firms excel at sustaining innovations within their value network (Ch 1) explains Airbnb's strength here. The listing evaluation page is the product of over a decade of sustaining improvements within the vacation rental value network: better photos, richer descriptions, more nuanced review categories, verified host identity, and AI-powered translation. These are all sustaining innovations that serve existing customers better along established performance trajectories.
listing_evaluation.what_nobody_in_category_does: Nobody shows you what daily life actually looks like in a shared living space. Listing pages across the entire category are static brochures — pretty photos, feature lists, and star ratings. No platform shows: what the host's communication style is like (response samples, not just response time), what other guests have said about the experience of sharing the space (not just the space itself), what the neighborhood sounds like at night, what the morning kitchen routine looks like with other occupants, or what happens when there's a conflict. The entire category presents an idealized, pre-move-in fantasy rather than an honest preview of cohabitation reality.

evidence.observation: Christensen shows that 'the way value is measured differs across networks' and that 'the unique rank-ordering of the importance of various product performance attributes defines, in part, the boundaries of a value network.' For disk drives, mainframe customers valued capacity and speed; portable computing customers valued ruggedness, low power, and small size.
evidence.framework_interpretation: Applied to Airbnb: vacation guests evaluate listings on aesthetics, location, and amenity completeness. Mid-term shared housing seekers would evaluate on roommate compatibility, host communication quality, and daily-routine practicality. These are fundamentally different metrics of value, and Airbnb's listing page is built to display the former while being structurally unable to display the latter without confusing its core vacation audience.

evidence.observation: Airbnb reviews are structured around short-stay metrics: cleanliness, accuracy, check-in, communication, location, value. There is no review dimension for 'how well did you coexist with the host or other guests over multiple weeks?' or 'how fair was the host when issues arose mid-stay?' The review system literally cannot capture the information a mid-term shared housing seeker needs most.
evidence.framework_interpretation: The review system's categories are a direct expression of the value network's rank-ordering of attributes. Changing them to serve a mid-term audience would degrade their clarity for the vacation audience — the same dilemma Christensen identifies when established firms try to serve two value networks simultaneously.

booking_proposal.what_they_do: Instant Book or Request to Book. Pricing is displayed as nightly rate + cleaning fee + service fee = total. For longer stays, monthly discounts are applied. Payment is collected upfront or split into installments. The process is transactional and one-directional: guest requests, host approves or declines. There is no negotiation mechanism. Cancellation policies are set by the host from predefined tiers (Flexible, Moderate, Strict).
booking_proposal.framework_analysis: Christensen's Ch 4 analysis of 'What Goes Up, Can't Go Down' reveals why Airbnb's booking model is structured this way. The one-click transactional booking model was designed to maximize conversion in the vacation value network, where speed-to-book and certainty of reservation are the primary user needs. Moving to a negotiation-based model (as mid-term shared housing requires) would introduce friction that degrades the core vacation booking experience. This is exactly the 'downward immobility' Christensen describes — the cost structure and UX patterns that make Airbnb successful in the vacation market make it structurally unable to serve the negotiation-heavy mid-term market.
booking_proposal.what_nobody_in_category_does: Nobody in the category treats booking as a bilateral negotiation between two people who will share a living space. Every platform — Airbnb, VRBO, Furnished Finder — uses a one-directional model: the host sets all terms, the guest takes or leaves. No platform allows the guest to propose alternative terms (different nights of the week, different duration, different price point) and have the host counter. No platform models the booking as the beginning of a relationship rather than a commercial transaction. The entire category treats the booking moment as a purchase, not a conversation.

evidence.source: Ch 4: What Goes Up, Can't Go Down — asymmetric incentives
evidence.observation: Christensen demonstrates that 'the most vexing managerial aspect of this problem of asymmetry, where the easiest path to growth and profit is up, and the most deadly attacks come from below, is that good management doesn't solve the problem.' Firms migrate upmarket because the resource allocation process systematically favors investments with known, larger, higher-margin markets.
evidence.framework_interpretation: Airbnb's booking flow is optimized for the highest-volume, highest-margin transaction type: short-stay vacation bookings where speed and simplicity drive conversion. Investing engineering resources in a negotiation-based booking flow for mid-term stays would address a smaller, lower-margin market segment. Every rational resource allocation decision at Airbnb would deprioritize this in favor of improving the mainstream vacation booking funnel — exactly as Christensen predicts.

evidence.source: Airbnb pricing and booking UX observation
evidence.observation: Airbnb's checkout flow is a single-page transaction: confirm dates, confirm guests, pay. For a 3-month shared housing stay costing $4,000+, the commitment process is identical to booking a weekend getaway. There is no step that acknowledges the magnitude of the commitment, no mechanism to discuss terms, and no way to adjust the proposal before submitting payment.
evidence.framework_interpretation: This is the UX manifestation of value network lock-in. The booking flow is optimized for the 2-3 night average stay duration that generates the majority of Airbnb's revenue. The same flow applied to a 3-month stay is 'adequate' — it works — but it misses the psychological gravity of the decision, which is a signature opportunity.

communication.what_they_do: In-app messaging system between host and guest. Pre-booking inquiries are supported. Airbnb provides response rate and response time metrics for hosts, incentivizing fast replies. Smart replies and automated messages are available. Communication is text-based with photo sharing. Airbnb monitors messages for off-platform contact attempts and policy violations.
communication.framework_analysis: Christensen's resource dependence principle (Principle #1 from the Introduction) explains the adequacy here. Airbnb's communication system serves its customers' primary need: coordinating logistics for a short stay (check-in instructions, wifi password, local recommendations). The system is not designed for — and Airbnb's customers have never demanded — the kind of ongoing, relationship-building communication that a multi-week or multi-month shared living arrangement requires. Because Airbnb's most profitable customers (vacation guests) don't need rich communication tools, the resource allocation process has never prioritized building them.
communication.what_nobody_in_category_does: Nobody provides structured communication templates for the phases of a shared housing relationship: pre-arrival expectations setting, arrival-day coordination, weekly check-ins, issue escalation, end-of-stay transition. Nobody builds communication tools that help two strangers establish house norms, negotiate shared space usage, or resolve friction points before they become conflicts. The entire category treats host-guest communication as customer service (transactional, reactive) rather than as relationship management (ongoing, proactive).

evidence.source: Ch 2: Step 2 — Marketing Personnel Sought Reactions from Lead Customers
evidence.observation: Christensen describes how Seagate's marketers 'tested the 3.5-inch prototypes with customers in the desktop computing market it already served — manufacturers like IBM and value-added resellers of full-sized desktop computer systems. Not surprisingly, they indicated little interest in the smaller drive.' The firms asked the wrong customers about the wrong product.
evidence.framework_interpretation: If Airbnb were to test richer communication features, they would test them with their existing vacation hosts and guests — who would report little interest, because logistics coordination is all they need. The mid-term shared-housing user who desperately needs structured cohabitation communication tools is not Airbnb's customer, so their needs never surface in product research. This is the exact dynamic Christensen documents: existing customers actively mislead firms away from disruptive opportunities.

evidence.source: Airbnb messaging UX and public host forums
evidence.observation: Airbnb's messaging interface is functionally identical to a basic chat app. There are no structured message types (arrival notification, cleaning checklist, issue report), no shared documents (house manual is a separate feature), and no mechanism for ongoing check-ins during extended stays. Hosts of long-term guests report using WhatsApp or SMS because Airbnb's in-app messaging lacks the richness needed for an ongoing relationship.
evidence.framework_interpretation: When the platform's communication tools are inadequate for longer stays, users route around them — a classic signal that the value network's needs exceed what the incumbent provides. This is analogous to early minicomputer users jury-rigging mainframe peripherals before the 8-inch drive emerged to serve their specific needs.

active_stay.what_they_do: Once a stay begins, Airbnb's role is minimal. The platform provides check-in instructions, a link to the house manual (if the host created one), and a channel for messaging. There is no active management of the stay experience. If issues arise, guests can contact Airbnb's resolution center, which handles disputes after the fact. For longer stays (28+ days), local tenant protection laws may apply, creating a legal gray area that Airbnb does not actively manage.
active_stay.framework_analysis: Christensen's description of how firms' 'cost structures characteristic of each value network can have a powerful effect on the sorts of innovations firms deem profitable' (Ch 2) explains why active-stay management is merely adequate. Airbnb's cost structure is built around facilitating transactions (booking, payment) at scale, not managing ongoing relationships. Investing in active-stay management tools — check-in workflows, stay-quality monitoring, date-change flexibility, mid-stay adjustments — would increase per-booking operational cost with no corresponding increase in fee revenue. In Airbnb's value network, the stay itself is the customer's problem to manage, not the platform's.
active_stay.what_nobody_in_category_does: Nobody actively manages the quality of the stay while it's happening. Every platform in the category is a matchmaker that disappears after the match is made. No platform provides: proactive check-ins at stay milestones (Day 1, Week 1, midpoint), a date-change tool for adjusting specific nights within an active agreement, arrival and departure documentation (photos proving condition of space), or a real-time feedback mechanism that surfaces issues before they become disputes. The category treats active stays as a black box between booking and review.

evidence.source: Ch 4: What Goes Up, Can't Go Down — cost structure lock-in
evidence.observation: Christensen explains that 'a characteristic of each value network is a particular cost structure that firms within it must create if they are to provide the products and services in the priority their customers demand.' Gross margins for firms in higher-end value networks are higher, compensating for higher overhead, but also making it impossible to profitably serve lower-margin, higher-touch markets.
evidence.framework_interpretation: Airbnb's cost structure is designed for millions of low-touch, transactional bookings. Active-stay management for mid-term shared housing is a high-touch, relationship-intensive service that requires more operational overhead per booking. Airbnb cannot justify this cost for a segment that generates lower total fees (one booking for 3 months vs. multiple short bookings filling the same calendar). This is the cost structure asymmetry that makes downward mobility impossible — exactly the mechanism Christensen identifies as the root cause of incumbent failure.

evidence.source: Public Airbnb host and guest reviews/forums
evidence.observation: Long-term Airbnb guests frequently report feeling 'abandoned' after check-in. Hosts of long-term guests report that managing mid-stay issues (maintenance, guest complaints, cleaning schedules) falls entirely on them with no platform support. The 28-day+ stay experience is functionally identical to a private landlord-tenant relationship with an expensive middleman who disappears after collecting fees.
evidence.framework_interpretation: This is the vacuum Christensen describes when an incumbent moves upmarket and leaves the low end exposed. Airbnb's active-stay experience for mid-term guests is the 'mediocre coffee' — nobody expects the platform to actively manage the stay, because no platform in the category ever has. But the psychological need is enormous, especially when two strangers are sharing a living space for weeks or months.

post_stay.what_they_do: Dual review system: guests review hosts (cleanliness, accuracy, check-in, communication, location, value) and hosts review guests (cleanliness, communication, house rules). Reviews are published simultaneously after both parties submit or after 14 days. Star ratings aggregate into the host's overall score, which affects search ranking. Superhost status requires maintaining 4.8+ rating.
post_stay.framework_analysis: Christensen's concept of sustaining innovation within a value network applies. Airbnb's review system has been iteratively improved over many years — adding category-specific ratings, verified guest ratings, response mechanisms, and algorithmic fraud detection. These are all sustaining innovations that serve the vacation value network's needs: helping future vacation guests assess whether a property meets their short-stay expectations. But the review dimensions themselves are fixed by the value network's rank-ordering of attributes, making them structurally unable to capture the dimensions that matter for shared living evaluation.
post_stay.what_nobody_in_category_does: Nobody captures review data about the shared living experience itself — how it felt to coexist with the host or other guests, how conflicts were handled, how accurate the 'vibe' of the listing was compared to reality, or how the host handled the inevitable friction of shared domestic life. No platform builds a review system that helps future guests predict their compatibility with a specific host or living situation. Reviews across the entire category are property reviews disguised as experience reviews.

evidence.source: Ch 2: Value Networks Mirror Product Architecture
evidence.observation: Christensen demonstrates that 'companies are embedded in value networks because their products generally are embedded, or nested hierarchically, as components within other products and eventually within end systems of use.' The architecture of the product (in this case, the review system) mirrors the architecture of the value network it serves.
evidence.framework_interpretation: Airbnb's review categories (cleanliness, accuracy, check-in, communication, location, value) are the 'product architecture' of trust in the vacation value network. Retrofitting this architecture to serve shared housing — which would require categories like 'cohabitation compatibility', 'conflict resolution quality', 'personal boundary respect' — would be an architectural redesign, not an incremental improvement. Christensen shows that architectural changes are precisely what incumbents struggle with most.

evidence.observation: For long-term stays, Airbnb reviews often contain buried information about the shared-living experience ('The host was in and out at odd hours', 'Kitchen was always clean when I used it', 'Walls are thin, bring earplugs') but this information is unstructured, inconsistent, and impossible to filter or search. The structured review dimensions capture none of it.
evidence.framework_interpretation: The unstructured review comments reveal latent demand for shared-living evaluation metrics that the platform's architecture cannot accommodate. This is a signal of a value network mismatch — the users are trying to communicate information that the system was not designed to capture.

retention.what_they_do: Wishlists for saving favorites. Email and push notifications for price drops and destination suggestions. Superhost loyalty creates stickiness on the supply side. On the demand side, retention is driven primarily by brand familiarity and network effects (most listings, most reviews) rather than by relationship continuity between specific hosts and guests. Airbnb does not facilitate rebooking with the same host for repeat stays in any structured way.
retention.framework_analysis: Christensen's Principle #2 — 'Small Markets Don't Solve the Growth Needs of Large Companies' — explains Airbnb's retention model. Airbnb needs massive transaction volume across millions of unique host-guest pairings to sustain its growth. Investing in host-guest relationship continuity (enabling easy rebooking, building long-term stay relationships) would serve a tiny subset of users and would not move the needle on Airbnb's growth metrics. The retention mechanisms are therefore designed to keep users on the platform (brand loyalty, wishlists, notifications) rather than to deepen specific host-guest relationships.
retention.what_nobody_in_category_does: Nobody builds retention around relationship continuity between specific hosts and guests. No platform makes it easy for a guest who had a great 3-month stay to rebook the same room next season, to maintain a relationship with a trusted host across multiple stays, or to build a portable 'shared-living reputation' that follows them across hosts and platforms. The entire category treats every booking as a first-time interaction between strangers, even when the parties have a proven, positive history together.

evidence.source: Ch 4: What Goes Up, Can't Go Down — vacuum creation
evidence.observation: Christensen writes: 'An important strategic implication of this rational pattern of upmarket movement is that it can create vacuum in low-end markets into which competitors employing disruptive technologies can enter.' As firms move upmarket, they leave behind not just customers but entire relationship models that served those customers.
evidence.framework_interpretation: Airbnb's upmarket migration toward one-time luxury experiences and away from repeat affordable stays has created a vacuum in the relationship-continuity layer of shared housing. A disruptive entrant that builds retention around host-guest relationships — making it easy and rewarding to re-book, building trust portfolios, enabling ongoing communication between stays — would fill a vacuum that Airbnb has structurally abandoned.

evidence.source: Airbnb rebooking UX and host community forums
evidence.observation: Hosts who rent rooms for mid-term stays report that their best guests are repeat bookers — but Airbnb provides no tools to facilitate this. No 'invite back' feature, no 'preferred guest' status, no streamlined rebooking flow. Hosts resort to giving guests their personal contact information to arrange future stays, which Airbnb actively discourages because it threatens the platform's fee structure.
evidence.framework_interpretation: This is the ultimate signal of value network misalignment: the platform's most loyal users are actively working around its systems to maintain relationships that the platform refuses to support. The incumbent's fee structure makes host-guest relationship continuity an adversarial outcome rather than a desired one — a structural flaw that a disruptive entrant can exploit.

split_lease_phase_mapping.discovery: Phase 1 (Host Creates Listing — homepage, listing wizard) + Phase 2 (Guest arrives at homepage and finds listing)
split_lease_phase_mapping.search: Phase 2 (Guest navigates to listing detail page — duration selector, day-of-week selection, pricing review)
split_lease_phase_mapping.listing_evaluation: Phase 2 (Listing Detail Page — nightly rate, 4-week rent, space details, photos, rules, features)
split_lease_phase_mapping.booking_proposal: Phase 2 (Create Proposal + Proposal Summary) + Phase 3 (Host Reviews/Counters Proposal) + Phase 4 (Guest Accepts Counter-Terms)
split_lease_phase_mapping.communication: Phase 3 (Notifications, Proposal Detail communication) + Phase 5 (Host-Guest Communication — arrival notifications, cleaning photos, general messaging)
split_lease_phase_mapping.active_stay: Phase 5 (Leases page, Stays Manager, Date Change Tool, House Manual)
split_lease_phase_mapping.post_stay: Phase 5 (Stay Review — mutual reviews after each stay)
split_lease_phase_mapping.retention: Phase 5 (Leases page as central hub for ongoing relationship) — Split Lease's multi-stay lease model inherently builds retention through relationship continuity

category_blind_spots.blind_spot: The entire shared-housing category treats booking as a purchase transaction rather than the beginning of a cohabitation relationship, with no negotiation mechanism for terms
category_blind_spots.why_nobody_tries: Every platform in the category derives revenue from transaction fees, which means their economic incentive is to make booking fast and frictionless (maximizing conversion rate). A negotiation step slows conversion and introduces the risk that parties won't reach agreement — both of which reduce fee revenue in the short term. The business model structurally punishes the very feature that mid-term shared housing users need most.
category_blind_spots.framework_insight: Christensen's Ch 4 demonstrates that cost structures determine which innovations firms can pursue. In the vacation value network, booking speed is the key metric because each night of vacancy is lost revenue. In the shared housing value network, booking quality (getting the right match with the right terms) matters more than booking speed. But no incumbent can sacrifice conversion speed because their revenue model depends on it. Christensen: 'the very processes and values that constitute an organization's capabilities in one context, define its disabilities in another context.'

category_blind_spots.blind_spot: No platform in the category provides active stay management — the experience between booking and review is a complete black box with zero platform involvement
category_blind_spots.why_nobody_tries: Active stay management increases per-booking operational cost without increasing per-booking revenue. Platform economics reward scale (more bookings) over depth (better stays). Additionally, active stay management creates liability exposure — if the platform monitors stays, it becomes responsible for stay quality in ways that a pure marketplace can avoid. The legal and cost structure of marketplace platforms makes active stay management irrational.
category_blind_spots.framework_insight: Christensen's analysis of the minimill steel makers (Ch 4) shows how disruptive entrants can profitably serve markets that incumbents cannot because they have fundamentally different cost structures. Minimills could make money at 15% margins in the rebar market because their cost structure was designed for it; integrated mills needed 50-60% margins. Similarly, a platform built from the ground up for mid-term shared housing can build active stay management into its cost structure from Day 1, making it a core feature rather than an unprofitable add-on. The incumbent cannot retrofit this without destroying its unit economics.

category_blind_spots.blind_spot: Nobody provides total cost transparency for multi-week stays — the category universally displays nightly rates even when the actual decision is a multi-thousand-dollar commitment spanning weeks or months
category_blind_spots.why_nobody_tries: Nightly rate display anchors users to a small, palatable number and maximizes the perceived value of the listing. Showing a total 3-month cost of $6,000+ upfront would create sticker shock and reduce conversion. Every platform's A/B testing has optimized for the pricing display that maximizes short-stay conversion, and that display is per-night. The same display applied to longer stays is misleading by omission (fees, cleaning costs, total commitment), but changing it would require building a separate display system for long stays — a niche investment.
category_blind_spots.framework_insight: Christensen's trajectory-of-improvement framework (Ch 1) shows that technologies improve along dimensions valued by existing customers. Airbnb's pricing UX has improved along dimensions valued by vacation guests: clearer nightly comparisons, better fee transparency at checkout, flexible payment plans. These improvements follow the vacation trajectory. The mid-term housing user needs a fundamentally different pricing trajectory: total commitment clarity upfront, per-period payment schedules, and cost-per-month comparisons. This is a parallel trajectory, not a continuation of the existing one — precisely the characteristic of disruptive innovations.

category_blind_spots.blind_spot: No platform builds host-guest relationship continuity across multiple stays or provides a portable shared-living reputation system
category_blind_spots.why_nobody_tries: Relationship continuity threatens the platform's intermediation value. If a host and guest develop a trusted relationship, they can transact directly and bypass platform fees. Every marketplace platform's economic model depends on being the irreplaceable intermediary for every transaction. Building relationship continuity tools is economically self-destructive for a transaction-fee marketplace. Additionally, the vacation segment (which is the core revenue driver) has inherently low repeat rates with the same host, so there's no customer demand from the core market.
category_blind_spots.framework_insight: Christensen's analysis of resource dependence (Principle #1) explains this perfectly: 'companies with investment patterns that don't satisfy their customers and investors don't survive.' Airbnb's investors demand GMV growth, which comes from new bookings, not relationship deepening. Investing in relationship continuity would satisfy a niche segment at the expense of growth metrics that drive valuation. The incumbent is held captive by its customers and investors, exactly as Christensen describes. A disruptive entrant whose value proposition is the relationship itself — not the individual transaction — can build this as a core feature because its economic model rewards retention over transaction volume.

category_blind_spots.blind_spot: The entire category lacks structured conflict resolution and expectation-setting tools for shared living — there is no mechanism to establish house norms, surface friction early, or resolve disputes without escalating to customer support
category_blind_spots.why_nobody_tries: Conflict resolution implies ongoing involvement in the stay experience, which increases operational cost and liability. Vacation stays are short enough that most conflicts can be endured or resolved post-stay through reviews and refunds. The vacation value network has never demanded proactive conflict resolution because the stay is too short for conflicts to reach crisis level. Mid-term shared housing is fundamentally different — conflicts compound over weeks and months — but because this isn't the core market for any existing platform, nobody has built for it.
category_blind_spots.framework_insight: Christensen's excavator example (Ch 3) is especially illuminating here. Hydraulic backhoes initially could only dig narrow, shallow trenches — useless for mainstream excavation contractors. But residential contractors who previously dug by hand found enormous value in even these limited capabilities. Similarly, structured conflict resolution tools would be useless to vacation guests who stay 2-3 nights, but enormously valuable to mid-term shared housing users who have never had any platform-mediated way to manage cohabitation friction. The feature serves a 'new application that had never warranted the expense' of the incumbent's full solution — exactly the pattern of disruptive entry.

sources_consulted: The Innovator's Dilemma (Clayton M. Christensen)2000.pdf — Part 1, Chapters 1-4: Why Great Firms Fail
Training knowledge of Airbnb platform UX, pricing, and market positioning (2008-2025)
Training knowledge of shared housing market landscape (Furnished Finder, Craigslist, HousingAnywhere, SpareRoom, Roomster)
